p: Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) is among the most common and distressing side effects of chemotherapy. [ 1] It has been shown to significantly affect the quality of life (QoL) and daily function of patients receiving chemotherapy. [ 2] Moreover, CINV, as a prognostic factor for overall survival, is so severe in some cases that it interrupts the treatment of primary cancer and increases the risk of disease progression, [ 3, 4] which result in treatment-outcome reduction.
